column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Use the Pursuit Intervention Technique ( PIT Maneuver )
#Text=in a Car

#Text=The Precision Immobilization Technique ( PIT maneuver ) is a procedure which has been used by law enforcement departments around the world ( this is also known by some as the Precision Immobilization Technique ) .
#Text=Vehicles at high speed are , by laws of physics and aerodynamics , inherently less stable than at lower speeds .
#Text=The rear of the vehicle is also fundamentally less stable than the front of the vehicle ( especially a RWD vehicle , under acceleration ) .

#Text=This is even true of aerodynamically designed vehicles such as NASCAR ; the PIT maneuver is also used in this sport , though most NASCAR drivers only complain when they are the victims of such a technique .
#Text=Before the PIT maneuver is performed , it is assumed that Car A is approaching Car B from behind .
#Text=The faster the speed ( freeway speeds ) , the greater the advantage Car A has .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Car A attempts to put the front quarter of the car next to the rear quarter of Car B.
#Text=It is usually performed while the two cars are almost touching each other .
#Text=A starting distance which is too great can cause danger to Car A .

#Text=At speeds greater than , Car B requires not much more than a good strong kiss from Car A. At speeds closer to , Car A may need to sacrifice a bit of the front-end of the car to give a strong slam to the rear of Car B.
#Text=After Car A gives the initial tap , Car B 's back-end will slide out if enough force was applied .
#Text=Car A will need to straighten out , so as to not follow through too much and lose control .
#Text=Car A then needs to slow down immediately to avoid broadsiding Car B.
#Text=For two comparable cars , Car A should always be able to slow down faster than Car B , due to efficiencies of braking in a straight line .
#Text=Be prepared for Car B to try to drive off as soon as it has slowed enough to regain control .
#Text=An experienced driver in a FWD vehicle could recover and drive off in the original direction at surprisingly fast speeds .
#Text=An experienced driver in a RWD vehicle will , once the vehicle is slowed most of the way , likely try to accelerate in the opposite direction of the initial pursuit .
#Text=AWD vehicles may be able to go either direction .

#Text=Additional aspects of the maneuver can be added to help Car A. For example , before the tap into Car B 's rear quarter , easing off the throttle ( or even using the brake a bit ) at the same time as the turn-in , will increase front tire down-force and increase traction for a very short period of time , which can add lateral velocity into Car B.
#Text=Tips
#Text=At freeway speeds , a hit from the side may not be necessary ; often a strong hit in the rear bumper at a bit of an angle may cause the vehicle to lose control .
#Text=With correct technique , a small car has the ability to take down even large trucks , but it becomes much more difficult .
#Text=Note- This is also used in racing sports such as NASCAR , and is one of the most effective moves to take out an opponent .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=This is a very difficult and dangerous maneuver , and should only be performed if you have been trained in the technique .
#Text=Any practicing you do should not be done on public streets !
#Text=Your own private property is the best .
#Text=Always drive safely .
#Text=Be observant of pedestrians and other vehicles .
#Text=Tactical or Technical Driving can be very dangerous , and it should only be done in emergency situations , when no other choice is available .
#Text=The P.I.T. maneuver is illegal in most states .
#Text=Do not attempt .
#Text=Successfully performing this technique will depend a good deal on the driving abilities of Car B.
#Text=If Car B is aware of Car A , avoiding the lateral force by simple swerves is possible ( professional PIT Maneuver training may also include evading the PIT Maneuver ) .
#Text=Never break the law !
#Text=Obey speed limits , research state and local laws , and be sure to obey all the laws .
#Text=While practice is crucial , it should be noted that many of the maneuvers can cause damage to vehicles .
#Text=Alignment , engine mounts , bearings and many other parts can suffer wear or malfunctions .
#Text=Some people use a cheap " practice car " to practice with .
